name: NewYorker
text:
In 1959, when humans began measuring the carbon-dioxide concentration in the atmosphere, there was still some margin of time. This is no longer the case.
https://t.co/UHld9uxJYj

name: NewYorker
text: After Bill Buford had given up on ratatouille for many years, he learned a new recipe in a French kitchen. "I liked this one so much that I have made it every summer thereafter, without fail," he writes. https://t.co/cj0SX7hVhR

name: NewYorker
text: “Turning a corner, I came upon a small crowd facing a police cordon. Behind the oﬃcers, a dead body lay on the curb.” @lukemogelson reports from Portland, the epicenter of this summer’s unrest. https://t.co/r7uDj63uqY

name: NewYorker
text: If Joe Biden is not guarding his approval ratings for a second run, he could push for more stimulus money, expand and reform the courts, move money from the Pentagon to build out solar and wind power, and more. https://t.co/y34aqTXy8Z

name: NewYorker
text: As a corporate lawyer, Eugene Scalia repeatedly hindered the efforts of workers to secure beneﬁts or defend their rights. Now he is running President Trump's Department of Labor. https://t.co/2baYt0VoQ4

name: NewYorker
text:
Our electoral rights are debased by those who claim that America is a republic in order to justify siphoning power from the electorate, @SueHalpernVT writes.
https://t.co/nzPkIQlYM2

name: NewYorker
text: "Dude, do not write in a third party. Don't write in Kanye. It's not funny." Ilana Glazer discusses the 2020 election and her Web series “Cheat Sheet for the Voting Booth." Listen here. https://t.co/BYxXrDOgn7

name: NewYorker
text: Two leaders of the progressive left discuss the Presidential race and the state of American democracy. https://t.co/MgvbazT1Zc

name: NewYorker
text:
Sofia Coppola distills the wry and rarefied delights of Bill Murray's style of performance in the new film "On the Rocks."
https://t.co/poZxJjm1x6

name: NewYorker
text: Nearly four million people in Florida have already voted by mail, but some two million more have requested ballots and not yet returned them. https://t.co/TAPpiYrguM

name: NewYorker
text: Squeamish Halloween lovers, this is for you: 10 of @tnyfrontrow's favorite classic horror films, without the blood and guts. https://t.co/H6SH32bqPv

name: NewYorker
text: With no fall season, and no “Nutcracker,” New York City Ballet asked choreographers to create socially distanced dance films, which are now premièring online. https://t.co/z5D5GusSVb

name: NewYorker
text: “It felt like the worst thing he’d ever done”: A short story by Roddy Doyle. https://t.co/vVkyR0m1V2

name: NewYorker
text: Chloë Sevigny, who stars in Luca Guadagnino’s HBO series, “We Are Who We Are,” introduces her baby to her old East Village stomping ground. https://t.co/aGBLNrCngz

name: NewYorker
text: In a year of lost normality, the West Coast wildfires’ outlandish size and reach are another sign that normal is gone for good. Yet the fires are not the end of the world. https://t.co/0s3mutda84

name: NewYorker
text:
Donald Trump’s Presidency is predicated on the idea that the United States government is itself an enemy of the people, @RohdeD writes. A past era of reform suggests a way out.
https://t.co/NNzOETSdxp

name: NewYorker
text: What does dance, which is so dependent on bodies sharing space, look like in the age of social distancing? What is ballet without an audience? New York CIty Ballet may have an answer. https://t.co/DH4PVmyXSd

name: NewYorker
text: After months of negotiations, Barack Obama asked Chuck Grassley, one of the two Republicans still participating in bipartisan talks about his health-care bill, if there was any change that could get him to back it. “I guess not, Mr. President,” he said. https://t.co/HzgQQjyDfp
